children.name: experience
children.definition: knowledge or skill that you gain from doing a job or activity, or the process of doing this
examples: experience of/in/with
You’ve got a lot of experience of lecturing.
my experience in many areas of the music business
experience doing somethingUS
I have a little bit of experience working in a hotel.
Ihadsomeexperiencein fashion design.
teaching/secretarial/political etc experience
The job requires five years’ secretarial experience.

children.name: have experience
examples: Applicants must have experience of working with children.

children.name: get/gain experience
examples: He suggested that I should gain some experience in a related industry like travel.

children.name: lack experience
children.definition: not have enough experience
examples: Some students lack experience writing essays.

children.name: broaden/widen your experience
children.definition: increase the amount of different experience you have
examples: After six years with the bank, he went to work in New York to broaden his experience.

children.name: considerable experience
children.definition: a lot of experience
examples: Margaret has considerable experience of hospital work.

children.name: long experience
children.definition: experience gained over a long period of time
examples: New prison officers are partnered by officers with long experience of dealing with violent prisoners.

children.name: useful/valuable experience
children.definition: useful experience
examples: That summer he got some valuable experience working in a tax office.

children.name: invaluable experience
children.definition: extremely useful experience
examples: Playing in the under-21 squad gives these young players invaluable experience.

children.name: relevant experience
children.definition: experience that directly relates to a job, subject, or problem
examples: Applicants need a degree and two years of relevant experience.

children.name: past/previous experience
examples: His only previous experience of broadcasting consisted of a job hosting a local radio station.

children.name: practical experience
children.definition: experience gained from doing something, not from books or study
examples: The classes provide students with some practical experience of computers.

children.name: first-hand experience
children.definition: experience gained by doing something yourself
examples: She has no first-hand experience of running a school.

children.name: a wealth of experience
children.definition: a lot of useful experience
examples: Between them, the management team have a wealth of experience.

children.name: lack of experience
examples: My colleagues kept making comments about about my lack of experience.

children.name: experience
children.definition: sth that happens to you or something you do, especially when this has an effect on what you feel or think:trải nghiệm
examples: After she retired, Hannah wrote a book about her experiences as a war reporter.

children.name: a good/bad experience
examples: On the whole, going to boarding school was a good experience for him.|I've had some bad experiences when I've been travelling on my own.

children.name: positive/negative
examples: The entire experience has been very positive.|Many people reported having negative experiences when dealing with their local council.

children.name: enjoyable/pleasant
examples: We want to make the experience as enjoyable as possible.|She recalled pleasant experiences from her past.

children.name: memorable/unforgettable
children.definition: a good experience that you will remember for a long time
examples: Meeting the queen was a memorable experience.

children.name: painful
children.definition: one that is very upsetting
examples: Her family supported her through the painful experience.

children.name: traumatic/harrowing
children.definition: one that is shocking and upsetting, and affects you for a long time
examples: Having an operation can be a traumatic experience for a child.

children.name: new
examples: The club scene was a whole new experience for me.

children.name: a formative experience
children.definition: one that has an important influence on the way someone develops
examples: The trip was probably the most formative experience of my life.

children.name: childhood experiences
examples: Our childhood experiences make us what we are as adults.

children.name: a religious experience
children.definition: one that makes someone believe strongly in God
examples: As a young man he had a profound religious experience.

children.name: an everyday/commonplace experience
children.definition: one that is typical of normal life
examples: The sound of gunfire is an everyday experience in the city.

children.name: have an experience
examples: I’m glad I had this experience but I wouldn’t want to do it again.
Ihada similarexperiencelast year.

children.name: experience of/with
examples: This was my first experience of living with other people.
Tonight on Channel 4, young people will be discussing their experiences of racism.

children.name: experience for
examples: Failing an exam was a new experience for me.

children.name: the experience of doing sth
examples: Simulators are very realistic, but they don’t compare to the actual experience of flying an airplane.

children.name: adventure
children.definition: /ədˈventʃəʳ/  a situation in whichexcitinganddangerousthings happen to you:

children.name: trải nghiệm , phiêu lưu
examples: ▪My grandfather used to tell us about his adventures as a sea captain during the war.
Ông tôi từng nói với chúng tôi về những cuộc phiêu lưu của ông như một thuyền trưởng biển trong chiến tranh.
▪ As a young man he went off to Africa, looking for adventure.
Là một thanh niên, ông đã đi đến Châu Phi, tìm kiếm cuộc phiêu lưu.

children.name: fortunes
children.definition: /ˈfɔːʳtʃənz/  the experiences that happen to you over many years, and how happy or successful you are, especially when this is told in a story, film etc: vận mệnh, số phận
examples: somebody’s fortunes/the fortunes of somebody số phận của ai đó, vận mệnh của ai đó
▪It’s a documentary about the fortunes of a group of musicians during the 1920s.
Đây là tài liệu về số phận của một nhóm nhạc trong những năm 1920.
▪ After he left London, his fortunes improved.
Sau khi rời khỏi London, vận mệnh của ông ta đã được cải thiện.
changing fortunes thay đổi vận mệnh
▪The movie traces the changing fortunes of a poor family in Southern Australia.
Bộ phim kể lại sự thay đổi vận mệnh của một gia đình nghèo ở Nam Úc.
fortunenounCHANCE
[ C or U ] chance and the way it affects your life
_Hehadthe(good)fortunetotrain with some of the world's top athletes.
_The family's fortunes changed overnight.

children.name: ways of saying sth happens to sb/sth
go through
children.definition: sth to experience a period of time that is difficult or unhappy:trải qua
examples: Kevin’s going through a painful divorce.
I've been going through a bad patch recently.
You'd think his children would be more sympathetic towards himafter allhe's gone through (= the many bad things he has experienced) .

children.name: sb’s been through a lot
examples: Betty’s been through a lot recently -- I think you ought to try and be nice to her.

children.name: happen to
children.definition: ifsthhappens tosborsth, it happens and has an effect on them, usually a bad effect: xảy ra với
examples: I wonder what’s happened to Dave. He should have been here by now.
A lot of people don’t seem to care about what is happening to the environment.
The crash wasn’t your fault. It could have happened to anyone.
Winning this award is the greatest thing that’s ever happened to me.

children.name: it can happen toanyoneuse this to emphasize thatsthis notsb’sfault
examples: The crash wasn’t her fault, it could have happened to anyone.

children.name: live through
children.definition: sth to experience a period of time when there are important historical events happening which affect people’s lives: trải qua, sống trong thời
examples: His new book is a collection of essays and fiction by writers who lived through the Great Depression.
He could never know the pain and fear this child had lived through.

children.name: experience
children.definition: if you experience something, especially anemotion, aphysicalfeeling, or an unpleasant situation, it happens to you: trải qua ,trải nghiệm

children.name: When you first tried a cigarette, you probably experienced a feeling of dizziness
examples: It was the first time she had ever experienced real poverty.
Many women experience feelings of nausea during pregnancy.

children.name: experience problems/difficulties
examples: Many old people will experience problems as the result of retirement.
Children need to experience things for themselves in order to learn from them.

children.name: experience difficulties/problems etc with
examples: They’ve experienced a lot of problems with their eldest son.

children.name: experience sth at first handexperience something personally
examples: It is shocking to think of boys as young as sixteen experiencing at first hand the horrors of war.

children.name: know
children.definition: know hardship/joy/sorrow etc to experience problems, joy, sorrow etc - used especially in literature:biết đến, biết thế nào là
examples: ▪In his seven short years, he has known war, famine and death.
▪ I don’t think I’ve ever known true happiness.

children.name: undergo
children.definition: if sb/sth undergoes a change or an unpleasant event, it happens to them or it is done to them: chịu đựng, trải qua
examples: He has undergone tremendous emotional problems following the breakdown of his marriage.
In the last few years the museum has undergone extensive renovation.
Part of Mrs Galley’s right arm was shattered and she underwent a five-hour emergency operation.

children.name: meet with
children.definition: to get a particular reaction, especially an unpleasant one, from other people:gặp phải, đương đầu
examples: ▪ The initial plan to sell off part of the company met with intense criticism.

children.name: meet with something from somebody
examples: ▪ Many working women still meet with prejudice from men.
▪ Rebel forces entered the town and met with no resistance from government troops.

children.name: sth bad that happens to you
bad experience
children.definition: bad/terrible/dreadful etc experience/ˌbæd ɪkˈspɪəriəns/ trải nghiệm tồi
examples: ▪You shouldn’t let one bad experience affect your decision.
▪ Being arrested was one of the worst experiences of my life.
▪ My passport was stolen and the police said they couldn’t help me. It was a terrible experience.

children.name: nightmare
children.definition: a very difficult, unpleasant, or frightening experience or situation :
examples: Traffic was a nightmare.
nightmare for
This has been an absolute nightmare for me and my family.
nightmare of (doing) sth
the nightmare of going through divorce
It was every teacher’sworst nightmare(= the worst thing which could have happened ).
a nightmare journey

children.name: an absolute/complete nightmare
examples: The whole day was an absolute nightmare.

children.name: a real nightmare
examples: The situation with our neighbours is a real nightmare!

children.name: the ultimate nightmare
children.definition: the worst possible situation
examples: The ultimate nightmare for any parent is to suffer the loss of a child.

children.name: somebody's worst nightmare
children.definition: the worst possible situation
examples: The outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease was farming's worst nightmare.

children.name: a long nightmare
examples: How can we bring an end to the long nightmare in the Middle East?

children.name: a living/waking nightmare
children.definition: something extremely bad that happens in your life
examples: Being told I had cancer was a waking nightmare.

children.name: a logistical nightmare
children.definition: something that is very complicated and difficult to organize
examples: Arranging childcare during the summer can be a logistical nightmare.

children.name: an administrative/bureaucratic nightmare
children.definition: something that is very complicated and difficult to keep accurate records of
examples: Dealing with so many new applications for asylum is an administrative nightmare.

children.name: a personal/private nightmare
children.definition: a very bad situation that affects only one person
examples: His personal nightmare began when he was arrested for murder.

children.name: be a nightmare
examples: The whole holiday was a nightmare.

children.name: become/turn into a nightmare
examples: Their honeymoon turned into a nightmare when they were involved in a car accident.

children.name: a nightmare begins
examples: The nightmare began when her mother fell ill.

children.name: a nightmare ends
examples: We just want this nightmare to end!

children.name: end a nightmare
examples: He longed for something to end the nightmare.

children.name: a nightmare comes true
children.definition: something bad that someone fears actually happens
examples: The company's worst financial nightmare has now come true.

children.name: the nightmare scenario
children.definition: the worst possible situation
examples: Emergency planners are trying to prepare for this nightmare scenario.

children.name: a nightmare vision
children.definition: a very bad situation that might happen
examples: The book gives us a nightmare vision of a family destroyed by one man's secrets.

children.name: a nightmare world
children.definition: a situation in which everything is bad and there is nothing good
examples: It's hard to understand how people survived the nightmare world of the concentration camps.

children.name: a nightmare journey/trip
children.definition: an extremely unpleasant journey
examples: Commuters are facing a nightmare journey to work due to the tube drivers strike.

children.name: ordeal
children.definition: a painful, frightening, or worrying experience, especially one thatcontinuesfor alongtime: thử thách
examples: The three week trial turned out to be an emotional ordeal for everyone involved.
The hostages were relieved that their long ordeal was finally over.

children.name: a terrible/dreadful ordeal
examples: The trial was a dreadful ordeal.

children.name: a long ordeal
examples: After thirteen days, the hostages' long ordeal finally ended.

children.name: a terrifying ordeal
examples: Bruce Gordon has described his terrifying ordeal in a shark attack.

children.name: a painful ordeal
children.definition: a very bad or painful experience
examples: The treatment she had to go through was a painful ordeal.

children.name: go through an ordeal
children.definition: alsoundergo an ordealformal
examples: (= experience something that is very bad or difficult )I'd already gone through the ordeal of a divorce once.|The girl will not have to ungergo the ordeal of giving evidence in court.

children.name: face an ordeal
examples: He faced the ordeal of caring for his dying wife.

children.name: endure an ordeal
examples: In his book, he describes how he endured the ordeal of prison life.

children.name: survive an ordeal
examples: The woman survived her ordeal and identified her attacker.

children.name: recover from an ordeal
examples: She is recovering from her ordeal after a bomb went off on the train she was on.

children.name: subject somebody to an ordeal
children.definition: make someone suffer something very painful or frightening
examples: Simon Collier was subjected to a horrifying ordeal at gunpoint.

children.name: spare somebody the ordeal of something
children.definition: not make someone have to do something difficult
examples: Thank goodness she was spared the ordeal of surgery.

children.name: an ordeal at the hands of sb
children.definition: used to say who has made someone go through something painful or difficult
examples: She has only just revealed her ordeal at the hands of her stepfather.

children.name: ordeal of
examples: She then had togo through the ordealof giving evidence.

children.name: trauma
children.definition: a very bad experience or shock that has an effect on you a long time : nỗiám ảnh
examples: June never recovered from the trauma of her husband’s violent death.
Multiple-personality disorder is usually caused by early childhood trauma.
trauma of
the traumaofmarriage breakdown
He had psychotherapy to help him deal with his childhood traumas.

children.name: lesson
children.definition: nounbài học

children.name: an experience which teaches you how to behave better in a similar situation in thefuture
examples: _There is a lesson for all parentsinthis tragic accident.
_My parents made me pay back all the money and it was a lesson I never forgot.
_We canlearnimportant lessons (= gainnew understanding)fromthis disaster.

children.name: have
children.definition: verbhad,hadEXPERIENCE có

children.name: time
children.definition: nounOCCASION

children.name: in
children.definition: prepositionEXPERIENCING trong

children.name: experiencing a situation or condition, or feeling an emotion
examples: _We watched in horror as they pulled the bodies from the wreckage.
_He's living in luxury in the south ofFrance.
_She left in a bit of a hurry.
_You're in great danger.
_Could I have a word with you in private?
_Have you ever been in love?
_Your car's in very good condition, considering how old it is.

children.name: based on experience rather than theory
practical
children.definition: relating to real situations and events rather than ideas, emotions etc →theoretical: thực hành
examples: practically[adv] in a way that relates to real situations and actions rather than ideas: thực tế
Many people have offered to help, but there is little they can do practically.
Theoretically, it's a good idea to live without a car, but practically speaking , it would be difficult to manage without one.

children.name: practical experience
examples: You have to gain practical experience before you qualify as a solicitor.

children.name: practical work
examples: Archaeology students are required to do a certain amount of practical work.

children.name: practical problems/difficulties
examples: The local Social Services Department may be able to help with practical problems.

children.name: practical help/support
children.definition: alsopractical assistanceformal
examples: There will be trained people available to listen and to provide practical help.

children.name: practical advice
examples: The booklets offer clear, practical advice on running your business.

children.name: practical use
examples: Knowledge without understanding is of little practical use.

children.name: practical considerations
examples: There are a number of practical considerations that must be taken into account when choosing a car.

children.name: practical implications
examples: He was well aware of the practical implications of his theory.

children.name: in practical terms
examples: In practical terms, the experiment is going to be difficult.

children.name: a combination of theoretical and practical training
examples: They haven’t thought about the practical consequences of the new regulations.
What's the use of theoretical knowledge that has no practicalapplication?

children.name: in practice
children.definition: used when saying what really happens rather than what should happen or what people think happens : trên thực tế
examples: In practice women receive much lower wages than their male colleagues.
The journey should only take about 30 minutes, but in practice it usually takes more like an hour.
It seemed like a good idea before we started, but in practice it was a disaster.
Officially, Robert's in charge, but in practice Hannah runs the office.
I can't see how your plan is going to work in practice.

children.name: exposure
children.definition: nounEXPERIENCE (sự) từng trải hoặctiếp xúc

children.name: see
children.definition: verbseeing,saw,seenUSE EYESchứng kiến

children.name: come under sth
children.definition: come understhphrasal verbEXPERIENCE

children.name: If you come under something, you are suddenly caused to experience or suffer it
examples: _Our armies have come under heavy bombardment.
_The government are coming under pressure to change the law.

children.name: ups and downs
children.definition: plural noun sự thăng trầm

children.name: If someone or something experiences ups and downs, a mixture of good and bad things happens to them
examples: _Like most married couples we've had our ups and downs, but life's like that.

children.name: witness
children.definition: verbHAPPEN chứng kiến

children.name: formalWhen a place or period witnesses a particular event, the event happens in that place or during that period
examples: _This university has witnessed quite a few changes over the years.
_The past few years have witnessed momentous changes throughoutEastern Europe.

children.name: experience
children.definition: knowledge that you gain about life and the world by being in different situations and meeting different people, or the process of gaining this

children.name: personal experience
examples: He spoke from personal experience about the harmful effects of taking drugs.

children.name: life experience
children.definition: experience that comes from life
examples: As an older parent, your life experience is one of your greatest assets.

children.name: first-hand experience
children.definition: experience gained from doing something yourself
examples: As a journalist living in Iraq, he had first-hand experience of coping with terror on his doorstep.

children.name: bitter experience
children.definition: experience that makes you feel disappointed or upset
examples: I knew from bitter experience how unreliable she could be.

children.name: everyday experience
children.definition: experience of normal life
examples: Hunger is part of everyday experience for these children.

children.name: know/learn from experience
examples: Janet knew from experience that love doesn't always last.

children.name: speak from experience
examples: The miners spoke from experience about the dangers of their work.

children.name: lack experience
examples: Many men in their twenties lack experience and social skills.

children.name: experience suggests/shows something
examples: Experience suggests that children who commit crimes will continue to offend as adults.

children.name: lack of experience
examples: He was embarrassed about his lack of experience with women.

children.name: in sb’s experience
examples: In his experience, women did not like getting their feet wet and muddy.
